s.text: In yeshiva, being true to yourself is possible only if you recognize that your true self longs to submit to the rule of Torah.
(He says the one thing he took from yeshiva was to be true to oneself.

Sequences that once were run together by a studio bent on linearity are now fractured and intercut in accordance with Welles' intentions, and the still-astonishing first shot has been shorn of credits and of the Henry Mancini theme that obscured its cacophonous sound mix.

So why do I recommend Rounders ? Because I'm a sucker--I was entertained.
Mike is supposed to be an honest connoisseur of card playing nature, a master whose expertise derives from spotting "tells," from "watching the player, not the cards."
Arounder is defined--in a handy glossary included with my press notes--as "[a] player who knows all the angles and earns his living at the poker table.
("Alligator Blood: A compliment given to an outstanding player who proves himself unflappable under great pressure.

Forty years late, Touch of Evil has arrived, and it's all of a piece.
The wide-angle lenses spread the images out obscenely, so that the whole movie takes on the sweaty fatness of Welles' Detective Hank Quinlan, and our own sense of space is continually violated.
